text: It’s August of the year 1278.
The two strongest rulers within the Holy Roman Empire confront one another fourty kilometres north-east of Vienna
to finally resolve their five-year-long power struggle.
The flower of European knighthood, several thousand of the finest riders on either side,
is preparing for the inevitable clash.
The decisive battle for hegemony in Central Europe is about to happen.

It’s the first half of the year 1261.
Ottokar II, King of Bohemia, having achieved a stunning victory in the recent Battle of Kressenbrunn,
forces Hungarian King Bela IV to sign an unfavourable peace treaty, awarding control over the Duchy of Styria to Ottokar.
Unquestionably, this was a big leap forward for the Bohemian King,
who secured his eastern border and strengthened his authority over Austria and Styria.
In addition, with papal permission, Ottokar ended his childless marriage with his ageing first wife
and married Bela’s young granddaughter Kunigunda, future mother of his legitimate children.
Although Ottokar’s latest gains were formally recognized by the incumbent King of the Romans,
the Bohemian King was aware that Richard of Cornwall was just a titular ruler of the empire with no real power,
but with a serious Castillan opponent on his back, who also claimed the imperial title.
Ottokar capitalized on the Great Interregnum within the empire
and elevated his already strong position by balancing between two claimants in the subsequent years
in order to make sure that by the time of the next election, he himself would be the strongest candidate for the imperial throne.
With his ardent expansion policy, on the eve of next decade,
Ottokar took advantage of local dynastic disputes and spread farther south acquiring control of Carinthia, Carniola and the Windic March.
Yet he didn’t stop there and in 1272 he managed to add the northern Italian region of Friuli to his domain.
As a result, Ottokar exercised control over the land stretching from Sudetes Mountains to the Mediterranean Sea,
definitely a boast-worthy feat.
But this time, serious challenges started presenting themselves.
King Bela of Hungary was dead and replaced by his son Stephen,
whose attitude towards Ottokar was, to put it mildly, lukewarm.
Even though the latter tried to placate his neighbour with a peace treaty,
the former heedlessly raided his borderlands until he fell ill and conveniently died,
having outlived his father by just two years.
It was a particularly eventful year as another noble shuffled off this mortal coil,
Richard of Cornwall, the nominal King of the Romans.
Inevitably, another imperial election was forthcoming.
This was what the Bohemian King had waited for, for a very long time.
Being at the apex of his power and prestige Ottokar felt he was an obvious favorite for the imperial throne.
But unfortunately for him, the worst-case scenario played out.
The electoral princes, dreading that Ottokar had grown too strong,
decided to turn down his advances and instead chose a minor count from Swabia – Rudolf of Habsburg,
whom they assumed, lacked the strength to single-handedly rule the Empire
and also was unable to regain the crown-lands the electors had claimed during the Great Interregnum.
Infuriated the King of Bohemia, himself an elector, obviously protested,
arguing that the Duke of Bavaria voted as a lay elector in Ottokar’s stead,
but the opposition was overwhelming and his efforts to block the election were futile.
On the 24th of October 1273, Rudolf of Habsburg was crowned as King of the Romans in Aachen Cathedral
thus ending the decades long interregnum period in the Holy Roman Empire.
While Rudolf was supposedly meant to be a weak ruler,
from the onset he showed signs of a robust politician and able diplomat.
Not only had he won papal support by renouncing the imperial rights in Rome
and by promising to take part in another crusade to the Holy Land,
but more importantly deciding that all lands seized since the death of the last emperor must be returned to the crown.
Moreover, he urged the King of Bohemia to come to the Imperial Diet held at Nuremberg and recognise the new king.
Rudolf’s action meant that Ottokar had to concede all of his territorial gains over the last twenty years,
leaving him with just Bohemia and Moravia.
Unsurprisingly, Ottokar refused to do so and was placed under Imperial ban by Rudolf,
who declared war on the Bohemian King.
Imperial forces besieged Ottokar in Vienna and simultaneously a revolt broke out in Bohemia,
all these setbacks eventually compelled Ottokar to yield, sign a treaty recognizing Rudolf as King of the Romans
and renounce his claims to lands he had acquired throughout his reign.
It was indeed a bitter pill to swallow but Ottokar didn’t give up so easily.
He spent the next two years building up his military potential and looking for allies eager to back his cause.
Just like twenty years earlier, Brandenburgian and Silesian dukes answered and joined Ottokar’s side.
In addition, he bought the support of the Duke of Lower Bavaria,
who was employed with the task of delaying the assembly of Rudolf’s army.
War preparations were at a peak and the summer campaign of the year 1278 was about to begin.
Ottokar’s initial plan was to march directly to Vienna, where Rudolf resided,
but the gathering of his troops took significantly longer than expected,
so he first attempted to storm two fortresses on the borderlands.
When Rudolf heard reports of the enemy’s movements, he decided to march out of the city and set a camp in the open,
so the light Cuman cavalry of the allied Hungarian King Ladislaus would have an easier time joining the imperial host.
Curiously, Rudolf set a rally point roughly at the place where Ladislaus’ grandfather
Bela of Hungary was defeated by Ottokar eighteen years earlier.
Thanks to the Czech’s own delays with troop gathering,
Rudolf was able to thoroughly examine the surroundings and relocated his camp closer to the battlefield he had chosen,
an open plain between the villages of Dürnkrut and Jedenspeigen, a suitable place for a heavy cavalry bout.
Eventually, early in the morning of the 26th of August,
the Bohemian host arrived in the vicinity and set a camp north of the plain.
While both armies counted roughly around 30,000 men each,
infantry units were meant to solely guard the camps,
while the proper battle, as was the custom,
was to be fought between both sides’ mounted units.
Several hours after dawn, with the morning sun already quite high on the horizon bathing nearby meadows in light,
events were set in motion.
Cuman cavalry archers began harassing Bohemian heavy knights forming their battle formation.
Unsurprisingly, they were unable to rout Ottokar’s units or cause any major damage,
but their plan was more to inflict fatigue and worsen the enemy’s morale.
Eventually, the ground trembled as several thousands of mounted knights with their armour blazoned by the August sun
charged and clashed with the enemy across the field.
The clamour of bent steel, shattered lances and human agony filled the surroundings.
Ottokar’s knights were not only more numerous, but also heavier equipped and better trained,
which soon became abundantly clear on the battlefield,
as Rudolf’s men, despite their efforts, were forced to yield ground.
At one point, even the German King was in serious danger,
as his horse was killed beneath him and only the swift reaction of his guards saved him from certain death.
Three hours into the battle, Ottokar’s forces were winning,
although fatigue became a serious problem for his steel-embroiled knights
as the summer sun was reaching noon.
Rudolf’s units were not in a much better condition, yet the German king had an ace up his sleeve.
Horns roared as auxiliary units concealed in the forest and lead by Ulrich von Kapellen
emerged from the woods to the west and charged at Ottokar’s unsuspecting right flank.
In the 13th century such action was still considered unchivalrous, and not many agreed to fill such a dishonourable role,
but the effect of this sudden attack on the weary Bohemian flank was about to turn the tide of the battle.
Though surprised, Ottokar reacted immediately and ordered his reserve line to turn back and attack the fresh German troops.
However, this manoeuvre was poorly executed
and for many of his fatigued knights fighting in the first line it looked like a retreat.
Their cohesion started to break, as one by one, Czech cavalrymen lost faith and ran from the battlefield.
Rising confusion eventually resulted in an uncoordinated retreat of the Bohemian troops.
Many of those who were unable to run were killed in the final phase, among them King Ottokar.
Cuman light cavalry pursued their defeated enemy and only increased the death toll.
The disastrous Battle on the Marchfeld was Ottokar’s last resort to regain his lands and power
through a direct confrontation with German King Rudolf.
Being unable to yield, he risked and lost everything.
In the immediate aftermath of the battle a period of political and economic turmoil descended on Bohemia,
as Ottokar’s son and heir Wenceslaus II was still a minor and virtually served as a puppet for various interests of local aristocracy.
The internal crisis lasted for a good portion of the next decade.
For Rudolf, the battle was a turning point in his career, as he eliminated his most serious opponent
and wisely used the prestigious victory on the Marchfeld to achieve his own political goals
and set a solid foundation for the future power of one of the most influential royal dynasties in Europe – the House of Habsburg.
